CONCLUSION: Violation of Article 6 - Right to a fair trial (Article 6 - Criminal proceedings;Article 6-1 - Access to court)
JUDGES: David Thór Björgvinsson;George Nicolaou;Lech Garlicki;Ledi Bianku;Päivi Hirvelä;Vincent A. De Gaetano;Zdravka Kalaydjieva
TEXT: CARDINAL . The applicant was born in DATE and lives in GPE .
CARDINAL . On DATE ORG convicted the applicant of several robberies and sentenced him to DATE and CARDINAL months’ imprisonment . By a judgment of DATE ORG upheld the firstinstance judgment .
CARDINAL . On DATE the applicant requested ORG to grant him a legal - aid lawyer for the purpose of lodging a cassation appeal with ORG .
CARDINAL . On DATE a legal - aid lawyer was assigned .

CARDINAL . By a letter of DATE the lawyer informed the court in a CARDINAL sentence - long opinion that he had not found any grounds on which to prepare a cassation appeal . This statement did not include any reasons for the refusal to lodge a cassation appeal .
CARDINAL . By a letter of CARDINAL DATE the court forwarded the lawyer ’s statement to the applicant . The letter read as follows :

“ ... ORG informs you that your legal - aid lawyer , advocate Mr PERSON , informed the court in writing that he had not found any grounds to prepare a cassation appeal . In consequence , the time - limit for lodging a cassation appeal by a lawyer of your own choice expires on DATE . ”
CARDINAL . The letter as well as the opinion were served on the applicant on an unspecified date .

CARDINAL . On DATE ORG refused to assign a new legal - aid lawyer to the applicant . The court stated that because the previous legal - aid lawyer had not found any grounds on which to draw up a cassation appeal , the mere fact that the applicant disagreed with this decision could not require the verification of this opinion by successive lawyers .

CARDINAL . The relevant domestic law and practice concerning the procedure for lodging cassation appeals with ORG against judgments of the appellate courts are stated in the ORG ’s judgments in the cases of PERSON v. GPE , no . CARDINAL , § § DATE , ECHR DATE ... ( extracts ) and ORG v. GPE , no . CARDINAL , § § CARDINAL , CARDINAL DATE .

CARDINAL . In its decision of CARDINAL DATE ORG stated that the refusal of a legal - aid lawyer to lodge a cassation appeal did not constitute a valid ground for granting retrospective leave to lodge such an appeal by another lawyer out of time ( V ORG CARDINAL/CARDINAL ) . It confirmed this ruling in a further decision of DATE . ORG observed that the court could only assign a new legal - aid lawyer to the case if it were shown that the first lawyer had been negligent in his or her task of assessing whether a cassation appeal had any prospects of success . If this were not the case , a court was not obliged to assign a new legal - aid lawyer to represent the convicted person and its refusal was not subject to appeal ( III ORG CARDINAL/CARDINAL ) . ORG reiterated its position in a number of other decisions ( e.g. II KZ CARDINAL/CARDINAL , PERSON CARDINAL/CARDINAL ) .

CARDINAL . On DATE ORG examined a case where a legal - aid lawyer had refused to represent a convicted person for the purposes of cassation proceedings , finding that a cassation appeal would offer no prospects of success . It held that in such a situation the appellate court was obliged to instruct the defendant that the time - limit for lodging a cassation appeal started to run only on the date on which the defendant was served with the lawyer ’s refusal and not on DATE when the judgment of the appellate court was served on the defendant himself . It stated that it was not open to doubt that a defendant faced with a legal - aid lawyer ’s refusal had the right to take other measures to seek legal assistance necessary for effective lodging of a cassation appeal ( III KZ CARDINAL/CARDINAL ) . ORG reiterated its position in a decision of DATE ( II KZ CARDINAL/CARDINAL ) and in a number of similar decisions given in DATE .
